| **Low retreat chance** | With three heroes that can each survive a full round of enemy attacks, you’ll never be forced to retreat. |

* **Jester**’s 35 % dodge and **Grave Robber**’s 30 % dodge give the party a solid buffer against surprise attacks.

## Bottom line
- **Vestal** gives you the *only 100 % bleed resistance* and the biggest health pool to survive the heavy‑bleed front line.

## Why this team beats every other 3‑hero combo

### 1.  **Turn‑order advantage**
* The two fastest members (Shieldbreaker 8, Hellion 6, Houndmaster 6) all act **before** the average enemy speed (≈5‑6 in Nightmare).  
* Acting early lets the party **trigger or dodge traps first**, apply crowd‑control, and finish enemies before the enemy‑damage‑boost (+15 % DMG) can compound.

### 2.  **Movement‑disruption resilience**
* The map is “trap‑heavy” → many effects that **stun, root or slow**.  
* Hellion and Shieldbreaker both have **90 % Stun & Move resistance**, the highest in the roster. Houndmaster’s 70 % is still well above the average and pairs nicely with his high dodge.

### 3.  **Dodge & survivability in Dark/Low‑Light**
* Dark lighting gives the **“higher surprise risk”** – enemies may get a surprise round.  
* High‑dodge heroes survive surprise attacks better. Hellion (30 %) and Houndmaster (25 %) are the two best dodge stats available; Shieldbreaker’s 23 % is also solid.  
* Combined with the **+10 % enemy accuracy**, these dodge values keep the effective hit chance well below 70 % (e.g., 30 % dodge → 70 % hit, then reduced by any enemy‑specific miss chance).

### 4.  **Stress management**
* The ally light‑level buff adds **high stress gain** each turn.  
* Resolve directly mitigates stress overflow. This team brings **5 + 4 + 3 = 12 Resolve**, the highest possible total for any three‑hero group (the only other high‑Resolve hero is the 5‑Resolve Hellion; the next best are the 4‑Resolve Shieldbreaker and the 3‑Resolve Houndmaster).  
* With 12 Resolve the party can absorb far more stress before a death‑blow is forced, keeping the “hero death = mission failure” condition safe.

### 5.  **Damage output & crit synergy**
* The ally light‑level buff also gives **+crit chance**. All three heroes already sit at 7‑9 % crit, so the buff pushes them into the 12‑15 % range, yielding a noticeable damage spike without sacrificing survivability.  
* Damage ranges: Hellion (10‑19) is the strongest single‑hit dealer; Shieldbreaker (8‑16) adds solid mid‑range damage; Houndmaster (6‑11) supplies consistent secondary damage and, in most versions, a **dog‑summon/taunt** ability that can draw enemy focus away from the more fragile teammates.

### 6.  **Balanced role coverage**
| Role | Hero | Reason |
|------|------|--------|
| **Front‑line tank / trap‑breaker** | **Hellion** | Highest HP (46), best dodge, all‑around resistances, biggest damage swing. |
| **Secondary front‑liner / crowd‑control** | **Shieldbreaker** | Same speed as the fastest hero, excellent stun/move resistance, decent dodge, can often **break enemy shields** (if the game includes that mechanic). |
| **Support / utility** | **Houndmaster** | Good dodge, decent HP, moderate damage, and (in most versions) a **summon/taunt** that can force enemies to attack the Houndmaster instead of the other two, buying extra time for trap navigation. |

---

| Alternative combo | Main drawback |
|-------------------|---------------|
| **Hellion + Shieldbreaker + Grave Robber** | Grave Robber’s **20 HP**, **very low resistances (20‑30 %)** and modest dodge (10 %) make him a liability in trap‑heavy, high‑stress runs. |
| **Hellion + Houndmaster (Resolve 3) + Abomination** | Abomination’s **7.5 % dodge** and only 40‑60 % resistances leave him vulnerable to the frequent stun/move traps; also lower Resolve (0) adds stress. |
| **Shieldbreaker + Houndmaster (Resolve 3) + Arbalest** | Arbalest’s **speed 4** means she will often act **after** enemy surprise rounds, losing the turn‑order edge; also lower dodge (15) and no extra HP. |
| **Hellion + Shieldbreaker + Houndmaster (Resolve 0)** | The 0‑Resolve Houndmaster cannot help absorb the heavy stress gain, increasing the chance of a death‑blow from stress overflow. |

No other three‑hero grouping matches the **combined speed‑breakpoint (8‑6‑6), total Resolve (12), and aggregate dodge (≈78 %)** of the recommended team.

---

## TL;DR – Recommended party

> **Hellion (5 Resolve) – Shieldbreaker (4 Resolve) – Houndmaster (3 Resolve)**  

This trio gives you the **fastest turn order**, the **best dodge & movement‑disruption resistance**, the **highest total Resolve** to survive the stress‑heavy dark catacombs, and enough **damage/utility** to clear enemies before the enemy‑damage boost can overwhelm you.  

Pick them, march into the Catacombs, and let the traps bite the dust while you stay ahead of the darkness. Good luck!

| **Tank / Front‑line** | **Man‑at‑Arms** (HP 55, Dodge 25, MoveRes 90, Speed 5) | Highest HP of the roster, excellent dodge (boosted by Radiant light) and the best Move‑Resistance by a wide margin. | **Healer / Utility** | **Plague Doctor** (HP 34, Dodge 15, MoveRes 60, Speed 8, DebuffRes 90) | Very fast – she will almost always act before the enemy wave, giving a high surprise chance. | **Dodge‑focused “glass‑cannon” support** | **Antiquarian** (HP 26, Dodge 25, MoveRes 60, Speed 6) | The only other hero with a dodge bonus that rivals Man‑at‑Arms. ---

### How the team meets the mission constraints

| Requirement | How the team satisfies it |
|-------------|---------------------------|
| **Survivability > burst** | Combined HP = 115 (the highest possible three‑hero total). Man‑at‑Arms and Plague Doctor can both soak damage; the Doctor can heal the tank or the Antiquarian when needed. |
| **Movement‑disruption enemies** | MoveRes totals **210** (90 + 60 + 60). Man‑at‑Arms’ 90 % MoveRes makes her practically immune to pushes/pulls/stuns, while the other two have respectable 60 % each. |
| **Radiant light (dodge bonus, surprise, low stress)** | Dodge pool = **65** (25 + 15 + 25). The light‑level bonus will push each hero’s effective dodge well above 70 % against most enemies, turning the tank into a “dodge‑tank” and letting the Antiquarian and Doctor avoid most hits. Speed 8 + 6 + 5 gives a very high surprise chance, meaning many enemy actions will be cancelled before they can disrupt you. |
| **Low retreat chance / hero death = mission failure** | The team’s high HP, healing, and dodge make a single death extremely unlikely. Even if the Antiquarian falls, the remaining two heroes still have enough HP and defensive tools to finish the run. |
| **Speed breakpoints** | Two heroes (Doctor 8, Antiquarian 6) are above the typical “surprise” breakpoint (≥ 6). This means the party will often act first, preventing enemies from using their movement‑disruption abilities on you. |
| **Balanced resistances** | Aside from MoveRes, the team also has solid **StunRes** (Man‑at‑Arms 90, Doctor 60, Antiquarian 60) and **DebuffRes** (Doctor 90, Man‑at‑Arms 70, Antiquarian 60), covering other common control effects that appear on the Weald map. |

---

### Quick “play‑by‑play” outline

1. **Turn 1 – Surprise**  
   - Plague Doctor acts first (Speed 8). She uses **Inoculation** on Man‑at‑Arms (full heal) and may cast a low‑damage **Miasma** to start a DOT on the nearest enemy.  
   - Antiquarian follows (Speed 6). She uses a **Dodge‑boost** ability (e.g., “Evasive Maneuver”) on herself or the tank, further raising dodge for the round.  
   - Man‑at‑Arms (Speed 5) then **Provokes** or **Blocks** the nearest melee enemy, drawing attacks away from the squishier allies.

2. **Mid‑combat**  
   - The Doctor continues to **heal** the tank whenever his HP dips below ~30 % (her heal is efficient and cheap).  
   - Antiquarian uses her **high‑damage, high‑dodge** attacks (e.g., “Arcane Shot”) to whittle down enemies while staying out of harm’s way.  
   - Man‑at‑Arms **holds the line** with his high MoveRes, shrugging off any pushes/pulls that the enemies throw at him. If a strong melee foe tries to flank, he can **Taunt** or **Shield‑Bash** to keep them occupied.

3. **When a movement‑disruption ability lands**  
   - Because the tank’s MoveRes is 90 %, any push/pull/stun will **fail** 90 % of the time.  
   - If the rare 10 % slip occurs, the Doctor’s heal and the Antiquarian’s dodge bonus will usually keep the tank alive for another turn.  

4. **Finishing the fight**  
   - The Doctor’s DOT and the Antiquarian’s consistent damage will finish off enemies while the tank continues to soak any stray hits.  
   - Because the team’s **stress gain is low** (Radiant light) and no hero dies, the mission can be completed without needing a retreat.

|------------------|---------------------------|

| **Flagellant** | No dodge, low HP, only moderate MoveRes – survivability is poor. |
| **Houndmaster** | Low HP, modest MoveRes, and his utility (summons) is less useful when you need pure survivability. |
| **Jester** | Highest speed but very low HP and the poorest MoveRes (20 %). She would be the first to be knocked out by a single push/pull. |
| **Plague Doctor + Crusader + Man‑at‑Arms** | While this gives the most raw HP, the lack of a second high‑speed, high‑dodge member means the party’s surprise chance drops, and you lose the Antiquarian’s extra dodge and speed buffer. |

---

### Bottom line

**Man‑at‑Arms + Plague Doctor + Antiquarian** gives you:

* the **biggest health pool** and **best Move‑Resistance** on the board,  
* **high dodge** (boosted further by Radiant light),  
* **two very fast heroes** to secure surprise and act before the enemy can disrupt you,  
* **self‑sustain** through the Doctor’s heal, and  
* a balanced set of resistances to cover the typical control effects on the Weald map.

This composition maximizes survivability while still delivering enough consistent damage to clear the mixed‑fight encounters on Nightmare difficulty without ever needing to retreat. Good luck, and may the light keep your heroes standing!
